Graphical abstract The proposed mechanism for photocatalytic water splitting over the CuFe2O4/AMO composite. The utilization of visible light for the photoelectrochemical production of hydrogen gas from water is a scientific challenge. Water splitting for the production of hydrogen using copper-ferrite and amorphous manganese oxide composite can be efficient way. This is the first report which focuses on the electrophoretic deposition of solvothermally synthesized CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide nanocomposites directly for photoelectrochemical water splitting under visible light. This study may provide a simple, cost-effective and environmentally benign method to promising photocatalyst and application for hydrogen evolution. Photoelectrochemical characterizations have showed that the photoelectrochemical water splitting performance increases when the mole ratio of amorphous manganese oxide increases. The photoelectrochemical measurements are conducted under visible light irradiation in 0.5 M Na2SO4 electrolyte. The best result of the photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution activity (502.8 μmol in 90 min) is obtained when the mole ratio of the CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide (1:4) is. It is observed that the as-obtained CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide nanocomposites are quite efficient photocatalyst for photoelectrocatalytic hydrogen evolution under visible light irradiation. Keywords CuFe2O4 Amorphous manganese oxide Electrophoretic deposition Photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution Visible-light 1 Introduction Hydrogen evolution has extensively been studied during recent years, and the photoelectrochemical (PEC) method has received more attention than the other tecniques [1]. To convert solar energy to chemical hydrogen energy, hydrogen production by PEC water splitting is one of the most crucial topics for decades. With the depletion of nonrenewable resources and the increasing problems of environmental pollution, it is urgent to discover alternative energy sources [2]. Among the possible alternative candidates, hydrogen is considered as the most promising clean energy resource owing to its sustainability and renewability [3]. Besides, hydrogen can be efficiently obtained from hydrogen evolution reaction that is one of the main reactions in water splitting, by adopting suitable semiconductor catalysts [4,5]. Photocatalytic (PC)/PEC water splitting techniques are hopefully arising ways for hydrogen production because of their environmental safety. Many researchers believe that the use of PEC water splitting technology is one of the most bright technologies for producing hydrogen gas to secure supply of energy and has attracted significant interest [6]. This is because water splitting is a pure reaction without any CO2 emission and solar energy is a high-power and infinite source. The hydrogen generation from renewable biomass derivatives and water through a PEC process is more efficient from the viewpoint of thermodynamics [7]. In general, the properties and band structure of a semiconductor electrode have a significant influence on PEC water splitting performance [8]. Spinel ferrites are compounds with the general formula MFe2O4, in which M is a metal. They are good candidates to become photocatalyst because of their relatively narrow band gap, which allows them to absorb visible light [9]. The advantage of CuFe2O4 is the direct band gap positioned near the optimal value of the sun spectrum. Moreover, it is economically convenient because of low cost. Constituent elements Cu and Fe are the most attractive if we take toxicity into account [10]. For this reason, CuFe2O4 is used as a photocatalyst particularly upon forming heterojunctions with TiO2 [10], SnO2 [11], Bi4Ti3O12 [12], C3N4 [13] or WO3 [14] in applications such as degradation of organic compounds and H2 production. Even if a basic PEC study has been described for the tetragonal phase of CuFe2O4 which is in the form of pellet [10] in the literature, there is a lack of knowledge about the fundamental PEC behavior of this material as thin-film electrode [9]. Manganese is known to be a needed element in many biological systems, and its reduction-oxidation chemistry is especially important in electron-transfer reactions. Manganese can also be used as photocatalyst to split water. Furthermore, manganese oxide is used in dry cell batteries, in ferrite production, as an oxidizing agent in organic synthesis, as a crosslinking agent in rubber, and as a component of oxidation catalysts. Also, manganese dioxide has been utilized as a catalyst for thermally catalyzed reactions [15]. Manganese oxide octahedral molecular structures have good semiconducting properties and are porous inorganic nanostructures, with an excellent catalytic activity owing to their mixed valent lattice structure consisting of Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ [16]. Genuinoa et al. studied the use of two Mn oxide catalysts, amorphous manganese oxide (AMO) and Pt/Mn3O4, to enhance the photodegradation of N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) present in high concentrations in water at neutral pH [17]. AMO may as well be applicable for the photodegradation of an organic pollutant such as NDMA. Recently, studies using AMO as a photocatalyst have been found in the literature [18]. However, there was no literature on the combined use of copper ferrite and AMO nanocomposite for water splitting. The novelty of the current work is that, for the first time CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites were used to produce effectively hydrogen gas by PEC method. In this paper, we discovered that CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites possess high catalytic performance on hydrogen evolution. Firstly, CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites were synthesized via solvothermal method. Also, the effects of structural and morphological properties of CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites were investigated. Secondly, the prepared CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites in different mole ratios were electrophoretically deposited onto indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass substrate for hydrogen evolution. Finally, the hydrogen production was conducted under visible light using PEC water splitting. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3.6H2O, >99%), copper(II) chloride dihydrate (CuCl2.2H2O, >99%), sodium acetate trihydrate (CH3COONa.3H2O, NaAc), sodium sulfate (Na2SO4), magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2.6H2O, >99%), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), oxalic acid dihydrate extra pure (C2H2O4.2H2O, >99%), acetone, hydrogen peroxide solution (35%), ethanol (>99.2%), and ammonia solution (25%) were purchased from Merck (Germany). ITO coated glass slides, isopropyl alcohol (>99.5%) and acetic acid (>99.8%) were procured from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). Ethylene glycol (EG) (99%, C2H6O2) was obtained from Tekkim (Turkey) and Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was purchased from Alfa Aesar (Germany). Deionized water (with resistance >18 MΩ/cm) was filtered by using Millipore Milli Q Plus purification system. All chemicals were of analytic grade. 2.2 Synthesis of CuFe2O4 and amorphous manganese oxide Copper ferrite (CuFe2O4) magnetic nanoparticles were prepared according to solvothermal method with some modifications [19,20]. In the first step, 0.3409 g of CuCl2.2H2O (0.002 mol) was dissolved with 10 mL of ethylene glycol. And then, 1.0813 g of FeCl3.6H2O (0.004 mol) was added into the previous solution. After dissolution of the CuCl2.2H2O and FeCl3.6H2O; 0.816 g of NaAc (0.006 mol) was put into the mixture and one more 10 mL of ethylene glycol was added to the mixture. Then 0.1 g of PVP was added into the solution and ethylene glycol was completed to 30 mL. The mixture was stirred for 1 h at 200 rpm. After that, the prepared solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-coated stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. After the autoclave was cool down, the obtained precipitate was filtered with the help of a magnet and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, and dried in oven at 70 °C for overnight. AMO sample used in this study was prepared according to the procedure reported in the literature [18]. To synthesis of AMO, reduction reaction between the potassium permanganate and oxalic acid was carried out. 1.58 g of KMnO4 was dissolved in 60 mL of deionized water, and it was added drop by drop to the solution containing 2.28 g of oxalic acid in 100 mL of deionized water. The obtained reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h at room temperature. The resulting dark brown slurry was filtered under vacuum, and the solid was washed several times with deionized water and dried at 90 °C overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites The (x)CuFe2O4/(1−x)AMO nanocomposites were prepared in different mole ratios by using solvothermal method [20]. For this purpose, mole ratios of the AMO and CuFe2O4 were chosen as 1:1, 1:4, and 4:1 (x = 0.5, 0.2, 0.8). With this choice, effect of increasing amount of AMO and CuFe2O4 on hydrogen generation was investigated. For preparing of nanocomposites in one to one ratio (1:1), the same mole of CuFe2O4 and AMO were solved with 20 mL and 10 mL of ethylene glycol, respectively. The solution containing AMO was added to the solution containing CuFe2O4. The mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. The resulting solution was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon lined stainless autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h to obtain the required nanocomposites. After the autoclave was cool down, the obtained nanocomposites were filtered with the help of a magnet and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, and dried in oven at 70 °C for overnight. The different ratios of nanocomposites were prepared according to the above procedure. 2.4 Electrophoretic deposition of nanocomposites ITO coated glasses were washed with acetone, ethanol, and distilled water, respectively in an ultrasonic bath for 10 min to clean. To remove the insoluble organic contaminants and activate the ITO coated glasses; H2O, H2O2, and NH4OH were mixed according to 5:1:1 (v/v) ratio, respectively and ITO coated glasses were put in prepared mixture. And then reflux distillation was conducted at 60 °C for 30 min [21]. The ITO coated glasses were then carefully washed with deionized water, dried at 70 °C under vacuum for overnight. For electrophoretic deposition; appropriate amount of Mg(NO3)2 as a binding reagent and positive charge supply was dissolved with 12.5 mL of isopropyl alcohol and then prepared nanocomposites which were same amount of with Mg(NO3)2 were added to mixture and one more 12.5 mL of isopropyl alcohol was added. The mixture was stirred with a sonicator at 60 Hz for 1 h. Two pieces of ITO coated glass (30 × 10 mm) were immersed parallel in the solution with a 5 mm separation. ITO coated glasses were deposited for 1 h using a constant potential of 25 V with the aid of controlled DC power supply source [22]. A schematic representation of the electrophoretic deposition is shown in Scheme 1 . After electrophoretic deposition, the deposited electrodes were annealed at 300 °C for 1 h. The as prepared electrodes were characterized with contact angle, atomic force microscopy (AFM), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV). 2.5 Photoelectrochemical water splitting experiments The PEC characterization was carried out via a potentiostat/galvanostat to investigate the hydrogen evolution using a typical three-electrode electrochemical cell system with an electrochemical analyzer. The deposited nanocomposites (CuFe2O4/AMO) onto ITO substrates were used as working electrodes, Ag/AgCl (saturated 0.3 M KCl) and Pt wire were used as reference and counter electrode, respectively [23]. 0.5 M of Na2SO4 aqueous solution was used as electrolyte for all of PEC measurements and electrolyte solution was deoxygenated by bubbling with N2 for 1 h before the experiments. The three electrodes were immersed in a solution of 0.5 M of Na2SO4 and were connected to potentiostat. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was chosen as experiment method with potential from -0.2 V to 0.4 V and the scan rate for the current-voltage curve was adjusted at 0.10 mV/s [14]. A 400 W Xenon (Xe) lamp of 100 mW cm2 light intensity was used as the visible light source and lamp was placed 15 cm away from the reactor. 100% of the light was transmitted on the working electrode. A transparent burette with scales was set out around the counter electrode (Pt wire) and the burette was filled with Na2SO4 solution up to top level of the burette. Hydrogen gas was produced at the counter electrode in the PEC cell [6]. The volume of collected hydrogen gas was measured for 90 min by directly reading the variation of the electrolyte level in the graduated burette for various times. Scheme 2 shows an experimental set-up for PEC water splitting. 2.6 Characterizations The crystal structures of the prepared nanocomposites were examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical, Empyrean, Netherlands) with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54 Å). The operation voltage and current were set at 45 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The morphologies of the prepared nanocomposites were characterized using a Philips XL30 SFEG scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The chemical compositions of the synthesized nanostructures were measured by Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) performed in SEM. The diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) of the photocatalysts were measured by using a Shimadzu UV-2600 UV–Vis spectrophotometer fitted with a diffuse reflectance attachment. The band gap energies of the photocatalysts were determined by the Kubelka–Munk function, F(R) and by extrapolating the [F(R)hv]1/2 versus photon energy (hν). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on Shimadzu UATR Two instrument (Japan) over the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1. The prepared ITO surfaces were characterized by contact angle (CA), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Wettability measurements were performed from water contact angle measurements using Attention Theta Lite goniometer. Measurements were made on sessile drops (4 μL droplets). EIS and CV measurements were performed using a CHI 660C electrochemical workstation. In this section of the present study, the prepared ITO surfaces, platinum wire, and Ag/AgCl were used as working electrodes, counter electrode, and reference electrode, respectively. The surface morphology and surface roughness were recorded using Nanosurf NaioAFM with tapping mode atomic force microscopy. The PEC measurements of the samples were conducted by employing a computer-controlled CHI 660C electrochemical work station with a traditional three electrode system. A voltage sweep was performed from -0.2 V to 0.4 V with a sweep rate of 0.10 mV/s. The three electrode configuration consists of a platinum wire counter electrode, an Ag/AgCl reference electrode and ITO working electrode. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of prepared nanocomposites Fig. 1 (A) gives the XRD patterns of (a) AMO, (b) CuFe2O4, (c) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) (d) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and (e) CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1), respectively. The corresponding XRD pattern of AMO matching with the standard XRD pattern (ICSD no. 98-006-8916) is displayed in Fig. 1(A)(a). AMO contains three peaks of low intensity appearing 25.07°, 37.10° and 66.10°, represents the crystallographic planes of (002), (100) and (110) similar to turbostratic birnessite [18]. Since the AMO structure is not crystalline, it is normal to give such peaks in the pattern of XRD. The AMO pattern is given to show differences in Fig. 1(A). In Fig. 1(A)(b), the intensity and position of diffraction peaks were in accordance with those of CuFe2O4 according to ICSD no. 98-018-4951. These peaks at 2θ = 18.35, 30.15, 35.52, 43.18, 57.12, 62.73, and 74.25° were attributed to (111), (220), (311), (331), (511), (400), and (533) reflections of CuFe2O4 with cubic spinel structure [19,24]. The corresponding XRD pattern of CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) is shown in Fig. 1(A)(c). The apparent characteristic peaks are consistented with CuFe2O4. The peak intensity of Fig. 1(A)(e) is almost the same as in Fig. 1(A)(c). For the CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) revealed in Fig. 1(A)(d), diffraction peaks of AMO can be observed. As the AMO mole ratio increases, the peaks increase (the new peak arised at 2θ = 33°) and a hausmannite (ICSD no. 98-006-8174) structure forms, which is a different form of manganese oxide [25]. Thus, CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites are thought to be successfully synthesized. Fig. 1(B) shows the FTIR spectra of (a) AMO, (b) CuFe2O4, (c) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) (d) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and (e) CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1), respectively. From the insets in Fig. 1(B), FTIR spectrum of AMO is showed between 400 cm−1 and 600 cm−1. AMO exhibits two broad peaks at 498 and 429 cm−1 in Fig. 1(B)(a). Compared to the literatures, AMO peaks have showed compatibility [19]. Generally, the absorption peak approximately 520 cm−1 and 460 cm−1 is conceived as the characteristic absorption peak of Mn-O bond [26]. The observed FTIR spectrum of CuFe2O4 has two absorption bands at about 450-600 cm−1, it is consisting of the octahedral (440 cm−1) and tetrahedral (572 cm−1) sites of Cu cations in Fig. 1(B)(b). The discrepancy between absorption peak of octahedral and tetrahedral complexes in CuFe2O4 is due to the distance of Fe-O on octahedral and tetrahedral sites [27]. The absorption band at 1653 cm−1 on spectrum is referred to the vibration of remainder H2O in the sample [28]. For CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites, when the CuFe2O4 ratio is increased, the FTIR bands show the CuFe2O4 characteristic, whereas the AMO ratio increases, the intensity of the AMO bands appears (Fig. 1(B)(c,d,e)). CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) sample exhibits one band of strong intensity at 508 cm−1, other band at 611 cm−1 (Fig. 1(B)(d)). Manganese oxide usually shows intense two bands between 400 cm−1 and 600 cm−1 [29]. The results obtained were in good agreement with that of the claimed values of FTIR by the other literatures. Fig. 1(C) represents band gap values of (a) AMO, (b) CuFe2O4, (c) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) (d) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and (e) CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1). Band gap values of the samples were calculated according to Kubelka Munk function which can be derived from the optical reflectance spectrum. According to this function, a graph is plotted as [F(R)*hν]1/2 versus hν and the resulting intercept with the x axis gives the band gap energy [30]. In this formula, R is the recorded reflectance in UV–vis spectra, h is the Planck’s constant, and ν is the frequency. With this calculation, the estimated band gaps of CuFe2O4, AMO, CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1), CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4), and CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1) were found to be 1.32, 1.60, 1.27, 1.45, and 1.25 eV, respectively. AMO has higher band gap value than CuFe2O4. According to the obtained band gap values, it is observed that the presence of AMO content in the composite increased the band gap and a blue shift to lower wavelength was detected. Results showed that the CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) composite which is green serie in Fig. 1(C) has the highest band gap value among the prepared composites. For narrow band gap semiconductors, the photovoltage is not sufficient for the water electrolysis taking into account the large oxygen over-potential over spinels [31]. Band gap energy of CuFe2O4 which is value of 1.32 eV corresponds to the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. This band gap energy can be comparable to the band gap energy reported by Cheng [32]. The band gap energy for CuFe2O4 shows values between 1.3 eV and 1.45 eV in the different literatures [33,34]. The morphology images of (a) AMO, (b) CuFe2O4, (c) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) (d) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and (e) CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1) are shown in Fig. 2 (A). It reveals from AMO (a) that less homogeneous structure exists in the view of particle size comparing with the other samples. The amorphous particles show porous morphology, which is due to the rapid formation of nanoparticles [35]. The AMO (a) shows diffuse rings or halos thus confirming the amorphous nature of it [18]. The solvothermal synthesized CuFe2O4 MNPs (b) were nearly uniform with good monodispersity and clustered structures. It is also obvious that CuFe2O4 MNPs are agglomerated as a result of its magnetic properties [36]. As can be seen in Fig. 2(A)(c) and (d), after formation of the nanocomposites, the agglomerated structures are different from the pure AMO and CuFe2O4. The particles of CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1) (e) have spherical and agglomerate morphology like CuFe2O4 (b) than the other nanocomposites owing to increasing CuFe2O4 ratio. The elemental compositions of (a) AMO, (b) CuFe2O4, (c) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1) (d) CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and (e) CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1) are defined by EDS analysis as shown in Fig. 2(B) and sum of analysis are given in Table 1 . The atomic fractions of Mn and O in AMO are 63.87% and 36.13%, respectively (Table 1). The atomic distribution of elements in CuFe2O4 (b) is Fe = 56.66%, O = 25.77% and Cu = 17.57% (Table 1). The Mn and O elements detected by EDS analysis, especially high amounts of Mn and O in CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) (d) probably indicate the covering of Mn and O to CuFe2O4 structure (Table 1). As it can be seen in Table 1, the amounts of CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites have changed as to ratios. In accordance with elemental mapping analysis (Fig. 2(C)), the nanocomposite CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) (d) showed an appropriate distribution of elements which confirmed the formation of homogenous structures, and the results are consistent with EDS analysis [37]. SEM and EDS results clearly indicate that CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites were prepared at targeted ratios. 3.2 Studies after electrophoretic deposition Wettability measurements were carried out for all surfaces using the sessile drop method in Fig. 3 (A). The change in the value of the contact angle (CA) shows the hydrophobic/hydrophilic character of the surface, which in turn can be related to CuFe2O4 and AMO structure as well as CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites. In this study, the equilibrium contact angles of ultra pure water, AMO and CuFe2O4 coating on ITO surface were found as 85.4°, 83.1° and 135.6°, correspondingly. The water contact angles of the ITO surface were 84° and 81.8° in different studies [38,39]. These variations may be attributed to structure of nanocomposites. Also, CuFe2O4/AMO (1:1), CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) and CuFe2O4/AMO (4:1) nanocomposites on ITO surfaces showed water contact angles of 90.5°, 68.6° and 106.4°, respectively (Fig. 3(A)). Hydrophobic surface possesses higher contact angles. Hydrogen bonding on the surface of copper ferrite is lower than the surface of AMO since oxygen can be bonded both copper and iron atoms species. On the other hand, since the oxygen in the AMO can only bond with manganese, the amount of free oxygen that can interact with water on the surface is higher in the AMO case. Thus, the water contact angle reduces. As the mole ratio of CuFe2O4 on the surface is increased, the contact angle increases also the water moves away from the surface. After the electrophoretic deposition, photographs of the coated surfaces are shown in Fig. 3(B). These results indicate that the surfaces of the samples are different from each other. AMO is very difficult to hold on the ITO surface by electrophoretic deposition. Also, the AMO coated ITO surface is leaving the surface quickly despite annealing. Therefore, this study also shows that the CuFe2O4 increases the adhesion on the ITO surface. Surface wettability, as one of principal surface properties of an electrode, demostrates a major effective on redox electron transfer and gas release in electrochemical reactions [40]. A hydrophilic surface enhances the extracellular electron transfer rate between microbes and electrode. In water electrolysis, the oxygen and hydrogen evolution are also affected significantly by the wettability of electrode. The result showed that hydrophilic electrode surfaces generate a much higher current density for hydrogen evolution reactions when compared with hydrophobic ones [41]. According to results of this study, when the mole ratio of AMO in the composites increases, hydrophility increases. These results show that CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) nanocomposites on ITO surfaces generate H2 gas further than the other nanocomposites. EIS can give information on the impedance changes of the ITO surface during the electrophoretic deposition. The Nyquist plot of impedance spectra of ITO surfaces consists of a semicircle part at higher frequencies corresponding to the electron transfer limited process and a linear part at lower frequencies corresponding to the diffusion process. Fig. 3(C) displays a Nyquist plot for all ITO surfaces. EIS was used to evaluate the surface layer kinetics for 1 mM ferrocyanide/1 mM ferricyanide redox couple solution. It can be seen from Fig. 3(C)(a) that the bare ITO surface exhibits a semicircle at high frequency region and a straight line at low frequency region [42]. Copper is known that has a good conductor of electricity. Also, CuFe2O4 has a conductivity of 9.1 S/cm at 800 °C [43]. As for the CuFe2O4, the Rct value substantially decreased to 8.89 Ω. Compared with CuFe2O4 and the bare ITO surface (96.03 Ω), the Cu2Fe2O4 modified on ITO surfaces enormously enhances the conductivity [34,44]. Compared to bare ITO surfaces, all coated ITO surfaces have enormous conductivity (Fig. 3(C)). CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) coated ITO surface (e) shows a semicircle and a straight, sharp line at 59.5 Z'/ohm. Thus, the conductivity of the redox couple is lowered compared to the CuFe2O4 coated ITO surface, leaving the load difficult. It is also evident that the conductivity decreases as the AMO content increases. The charge transfer speed of CuFe2O4/AMO coated ITO surface (e) decreased according to the CuFe2O4 coated ITO and the AMO coated ITO surfaces [45], suggesting the easiest electron transfer, and consequently, the most favorable hydrogen evolution [37]. This result indicates that CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites have lower resistance implying the improved electron transfer, which defined that they possessed easily electron transfer. Fig. 3(D) demonstrates the CVs of [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− redox couple solution in 0.1 M KCl on all ITO surfaces. The bare ITO (a) exhibits well-defined electrochemical characteristics with a couple of redox peaks for the [Fe(CN)6]3−/4− mediator and shows an oxidation peak current (Ipa) of 0.93 mA. The measurements were conducted in the potential range from -0.4 to 1.0 V. After the ITO was modified with CuFe2O4 MNPs and AMO, peak currents significantly enhanced. According to shape and symmetry of the curves, it is observed that the prepared samples onto ITO electrode show an ideal electrochemical capacitive behavior. The symmetry and quick reverse of current during measurement indicates fast charge transfer at the electrode surface [46]. Besides, integrated area of the cyclic voltagram shows the ion adsorption capacity [47]. Results obviously showed that, the CV curve of the AMO electrode has the largest range, so AMO shows the best electrosorption performance. From the CV measurements, electrochemical conduction and valence band energies can also be calculated with the equations of EHOMO= −(Eox + 4.4) and ELUMO= −(Ered + 4.4) [48]. According to calculations, the conduction and valence band energies of the CuFe2O4 and AMO were found as −5.1 eV, −4.20 eV, and −4.95 eV, −4.12 eV respectively. Thus, it can be seen that CuFe2O4 has more negative conduction band energy than AMO whereas valence band energy of AMO has more positive than CuFe2O4. This is a desirable situation for composite structures because of the recombination problem. If conduction band level of one of the composite material is more negative than the other, electrons flow to conduction band of the other composite material. Similary, holes pass from less positive valance band level to more positive one. This heterojunction system is greatly helpful to decrease the recombination problem of the photocatalysts. Moreover; conduction and valance band potentials have a crucial role on H2 production. According to basic principles of photoelectrochemical water splitting, conduction band edge of the selected photocatalyst should be more negative than the reduction potential of the water. Meanwhile; the position of valance band edge should be more positive than the oxidation potential of water [49]. Thus, the positions of conduction and valance band of semiconductor are important parameter in H2 evolution efficiency. It is accepted that the surface area, energy levels of photo-induced electrons and bandgap width of the photocatalyst can completely determine the hydrogen evolution of semiconductor photocatalysts [32]. Fig. 4 presents AFM images of all ITO surfaces. The AFM images of the clean ITO samples consist of grainy structures, with a root mean square (Sq) roughness of 3.63 nm on a 10 × 10 μm scale in Fig. 4(a) [21]. Fig. 4(b) and (c) show the surface topography of the CuFe2O4 and AMO on the ITO surface, respectively, which are significantly different from the topography in Fig. 4(a). CuFe2O4 (b) deposited ITO consists of a root mean square (Sq) roughness of 94.74 nm on a 1.5 × 1.5 μm scale. These agglomerate structures have various sizes and geometries [50]. AMO (c) coated ITO surface has a (Sq) roughness of 134.25 nm on a 1.5 × 1.5 μm scale (Table 2 ) and is bigger Sq compared to CuFe2O4 (b) coated ITO surface. We can say that this is due to the structural difference of AMO. After deposition of CuFe2O4/AMO, the electrode surface structure have a small Sq roughness as seen in Fig. 4(d), (e) and (f). A Sq roughness value of 65.44 nm on a 1.5 × 1.5 μm scale was achieved for CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4). As the nanocomposite material is coated on ITO surface, the phase differences have clearly appeared. Consequently, Sq rms value decreased to 64.92, 65.45 and 76.32 nm due to deposition of CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites onto ITO surface (Table 2). It is acknowledged that catalytic activity of the semiconductor photocatalysts is related to the properties of the surface area especially surface roughness which can be an important effect on hydrogen evolution efficiency. If the catalyst has the high surface area, catalytically active regions enhances. When the mole ratio of CuFe2O4 increases, Sq rms value increases because of the formation of gaseous byproducts and particle aggregation [51]. The improvement of PEC performances under visible-light illumination for CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) nanocomposite is expected to increase greatly due to high surface roughness [52]. 3.3 H2 production using photoelectrochemical water splitting Hydrogen production from solar water splitting using appropriate semiconductor photocatalysts is an intended requrest for all humanity and environment. This intended production is a challenge reaction and requires a convenient photocatalyst to split water, so choosing of photocatalyst matter is an important step. The oxide support undergoes partial reduction and is not a simple spectator, facilitating the dissociation of water and in some cases modifying the chemical properties of the supported metal. The working principle of CuFe2O4/AMO heterojunction composite was schematically shown in Scheme 3 . Band positions of the CuFe2O4 and AMO were found according to HOMO and LUMO values calculated from the CV results. In cyclic voltammetry measurements, conduction band level of copper ferrite was found more negative than that of AMO and valence band position of AMO was determined more positive than copper ferrite. When CuFe2O4 and AMO absorptions take place under visible light illuminaton, the photo-generated electrons of each semiconductor pass from the valence band to conduction band. With the light irradiation, photo-generated electrons moves from valence band to conduction band and photoexcited holes (h+) are produced in the valence band. These holes will preferentially oxidize H2O to O2. On the other hand, excited electrons (e−) in conduction band of CuFe2O4 can be more efficiently transferred to conduction band of AMO since the conduction band energy of CuFe2O4 (−5.1 eV) is more negative than that of AMO (−4.95 eV). Thus, the conduction band energy level of AMO is improved and the reduction ability of electrons on AMO conduction band is also enhanced. Then the more reductive photoelectrons move to the counter electrode (Pt) for the reduction of water. Besides, the valence band energy of AMO (−4.12 eV) has more positive value than that of CuFe2O4 (−4.20 eV) so photo-generated holes (h+) pass from AMO valence band to the CuFe2O4 valence band. Consequently, recombination problem that is one of the most challenge issue in photocatalysts can be solved with the heterojunction mechanism. In the measurement, there was a lag time of approximately 10 min for H2 evolution because of the time required to homogenize the gas phase during measurement [53]. Following a 90 min PEC reaction, stable evolution of consistent amounts of H2 was detected. The results showed that CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) composite demonstrated the highest H2 evolution rate of 502.8 μmol in 90 min (about 12 mL) which is about nearly 15 times higher than that of bare CuFe2O4 since the bare CuFe2O4 sample cannot efficiently produce H2 gas and it showed the lowest H2 production activity among prepared samples (Fig. 5 ). In addition, LSV curve of CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) photoanode was shown in insert Fig. 5, using 400 W Xe lamp, in an aqueous 0.5 M Na2SO4 solution. The photocurrent density of the CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) photoanode in the presence of 0.5 M Na2SO4 is substantially decreasing. It should be pointed out that the H2 production rate increases with the increasing of mole ratio of AMO in the composites. Significant enhancement in visible light H2 generation on the CuFe2O4/AMO molar ratio (1:4) composite was observed as compared with AMO, CuFe2O4 and the other nanocomposite films. The power supply, electrolyte, reaction time, counter electrode, reference electrode and the amount of photocatalyst used for hydrogen production is the same. However the photocatalyst used is different. Accordingly, when CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) was used, more H2 production was realized at the same reaction time. The all characterization data suggest that the AMO is similar to H+ birnessite or layered biogenic manganese oxides that contain cation vacancies in the structure with hexagonal unit cells. These factors are influential in catalytic activity. Hence, amorphous manganese oxides are potential candidates for commercial water splitting. The high catalytic activity of AMO is related to its structure, which is a layered manganese oxide analogous to hexagonal birnessite with cation vacancies in the MnO2 sheet. Cation vacancies in AMO are influential in catalytic activity due to coordinatively unsaturated oxygens that are excellent sites for proton binding [18]. In addition, for narrow band gap semiconductors, the photovoltage is not sufficient for the water electrolysis taking into account the large oxygen over-potential over spinels [31]. However, in heterogeneous photocatalysis the electron exchange occurs isoenergetically and the large difference between the conduction band (CB) of CuFe2O4 and the redox couple H2O/H2 (≈1 V) leads to a weak photoactivity. The advantage of CuFe2O4 is the direct band gap positioned near the optimal value of the sun spectrum and the high energy of CB, giving the photo electrons a strong reducing ability [10]. The amount of the evolved H2 is nearly linear increasing as a function of the measurement time. The volume of H2 produced can vary according to the type of electrolyte solution and pH. Compared to many previous studies, the yield of produced H2 is considerable high with using the CuFe2O4/AMO (1:4) nanocomposite. Kezzim et al. studied CuFe2O4/TiO2 hetero-system for hydrogen evolution and they found the amount of evolved H2 gas as 160 μmol in 90 min [10]. Helaili et al. have investigated photoelectrochemical properties of CuFe2O4, CoFe2O4 and ZnFe2O4 ferrospinels for water photo-reduction and they found evolved H2 gas as 130 μmol in 60 min using 50 mg spinel CuFe2O4 [34]. Cheng et al. reported the H2 evolution rate of 76 μmol h−1 by using CuFe2O4/g-C3N4 photocatalyst for enhanced visible-light hydrogen evolution [32]. Boumaza et al. prepared CuCr2O4 by using chemical co-precipitation method. Also, they obtained H2-photoproduction in (NaOH 0.5 M, Na2S2O3 0.025 M) with an average rate of 0.013 cm3 h−1 (mg catalyst)−1 [54]. Gan et al. studied visible-light-sensitive PEC photocathodes based on nano-engineered bismuth oxyiodide (BiOI) and plasmonic Au nanoparticles (NPs) on hydrogen-reduced BiOI (H-BiOI) nanoflake arrays. They found that a larger photocurrent enhancement was observed for Au@H- BiOI and H2 molecules are generated 29.0 μmol/h cm2 by the Au@H-BiOI [55]. Boudjemaa et al. synthesized FeCr2O4 using Cr(NO3)3 and Fe(NO3)3. They observed photocatalytic H2-production for 250 mg FeCr2O4 as 280 μmol g−1 s−1 at 723 K [31]. According to these studies, both using of CuFe2O4 and AMO samples was the sensible and efficient way for good yield of H2 production. These results apparently indicate the usability of the electrophorotic deposition of surface with hydrogen evolution catalysts and thin semiconductor materials in the case of powder-based photoelectrodes. 4 Conclusion Hydrogen is the ideal fossil fuel for the future because it is clean and portable energy carrier. As various technologies can be used to produce hydrogen, only some of them can be considered environment friendly. In this study, prepared copper ferrite and AMO nanocomposites could be a good candidate as a photocatalyst for water splitting. We have successfully tested the new hetero-system CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites for the PEC water splitting. The as-prepared CuFe2O4/AMO nanocomposites exhibited several advantages such as stability, monodispersity, low-cost, simplicity and rapid separation performance comparison of other catalysts. This study displays a new cost-effective approach for constructing composite catalysts of spinel ferrites and amorphous mangan oxide for hydrogen production under visible light irridation. Also, it is revealed that the PEC hydrogen yield increases when the amount of AMO increases. It is believed that this study may open up new gates to obtain the production of hydrogen evolution used in energy applications. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of visible light for the photoelectrochemical production of hydrogen gas from water is a scientific challenge. Water splitting for the production of hydrogen using copper-ferrite and amorphous manganese oxide composite can be efficient way. This is the first report which focuses on the electrophoretic deposition of solvothermally synthesized CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide nanocomposites directly for photoelectrochemical water splitting under visible light. This study may provide a simple, cost-effective and environmentally benign method to promising photocatalyst and application for hydrogen evolution. Photoelectrochemical characterizations have showed that the photoelectrochemical water splitting performance increases when the mole ratio of amorphous manganese oxide increases. The photoelectrochemical measurements are conducted under visible light irradiation in 0.5 M Na2SO4 electrolyte. The best result of the photoelectrochemical hydrogen evolution activity (502.8 μmol in 90 min) is obtained when the mole ratio of the CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide (1:4) is. It is observed that the as-obtained CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide nanocomposites are quite efficient photocatalyst for photoelectrocatalytic hydrogen evolution under visible light irradiation.
coredata.dc:title: New CuFe2O4/amorphous manganese oxide nanocomposites used as photocatalysts in photoelectrochemical water splitting
